com.ibm.lpex.alef
Class LpexTextViewer

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.ibm.lpex.alef.LpexTextViewer
Direct Known Subclasses:
LpexSourceViewer
public class LpexTextViewer
extends java.lang.Object
implements com.ibm.jface.text.ITextViewer, com.ibm.jface.text.IDocumentListener, com.ibm.swt.events.VerifyListener, com.ibm.jface.text.ITextOperationTarget

A line-oriented, LPEX-based partial implementation of com.ibm.jface.text.ITextViewer. One major difference from TextViewer, this viewer's stream-oriented IDocument is not kept up-to-date with the text changes in the underlying LPEX text widget. Always use LpexView to query the text of the edited document.

Several TextViewer classes, methods, and fields are not available in LpexTextViewer. Most programming of the underlying LPEX widget should be done directly via its LpexView and LpexWindow.

TextViewer classes, methods, and fields not available or not implemented in LpexTextViewer are listed below, along with explanations and the LPEX alternatives. While the list is rather long, it should be noted that several methods (such as those geared towards specific Eclipse solutions, like the shift-string operations, or those specific to the underlying StyledText) shouldn't be defined in here in the first place if one plans to leave room for alternative text widgets/viewers; also, the list includes protected stuff (some of which should have been private anyway) found in the original TextViewer.

  • protected StyledText fTextWidget, protected StyledText createTextWidget(), public StyledText getTextWidget()
    -- an LPEX widget is used, rather than StyledText. Method getTextWidget() returns null: use getLpexWindow() and getLpexView() instead
  • protected IUndoManager fUndoManager, public void setUndoManager()
    -- LPEX uses its own built-in undo manager (with unlimited undo/redo capabilitites), therefore it does not support IUndoManager
  • implements IFindReplaceTarget, public boolean canPerformFind(), public int findAndSelect(), public String getSelectionText(), public void replaceSelection(), public IFindReplaceTarget getFindReplaceTarget()
    -- LPEX does its own findAndReplace action, which is currently implemented as a live find and replace at the bottom of its window
  • protected TextDoubleClickStrategyConnector fDoubleClickStrategyConnector, protected class TextDoubleClickStrategyConnector, public void setTextDoubleClickStrategy()
    -- LPEX has its own double-click actions, therefore it doesn't support ITextDoubleClickStrategy. Token/word selection and bracket matching can be customized via new LpexActions
  • protected boolean fAutoIndent, protected boolean fIgnoreAutoIndent, protected Map fAutoIndentStrategies, public void setAutoIndentStrategy(), protected void customizeDocumentCommand() -- an LPEX language parser handles its own autoindent, therefore IAutoIndentStrategy is not supported
  • public boolean isBlockSelected()
    -- LPEX has various selection types and implements its own block operations. See the block command and related references
  • protected void deleteText()
    -- LPEX does its own textpartDelete action for the "Delete" and "Del" keys which are taken over by the workbench and sent as Delete actions
  • protected void internalRevealRange()
    -- the cursor is always visible in LPEX
  • public void setTextColor(Color), public void setTextColor(Color, int, int, boolean), public void changeTextPresentation(), protected void addPresentation(), protected void replacePresentation()
    -- LPEX parsers set display attributes to text in the parsed document. Also, LPEX marks can be set with certain style, visibility, and protection attributes. See the mark and related parameters
  • protected ChildDocumentManager fChildDocumentManager, protected ChildDocumentManager getChildDocumentManager()
    -- LPEX parsers that manage mixed-content documents may use appropriate subparsers (including available lexers) for the various document sections
  • protected static class ShiftPositionUpdater, protected static final String SHIFTING, protected int getFirstCompleteLineOfRegion().
Other notable differences:
  • void setInput(Object input)
    -- use the setInput() method prior to createControl(), in order to specify the com.ibm.eclipse.core.resources.IFile / java.io.File input object for this text viewer
  • public boolean doSaveAction(IProgressMonitor monitor) throws CoreException
    -- this method does a straight save of the LPEX text widgets contents to the local IFile / File. This method must be used to do a save, as LpexTextViewer does not keep its IDocument up-to-date. Also, this method takes into account the save.trim and save.textLimit parameters of the LPEX save command.

See Also:
ITextViewer, getLpexView(), getLpexWindow()

Method Detail

initializeStyles

protected void initializeStyles(int styles)
Initializes the style bits of the viewer. If the style bits include SWT.READ_ONLY, method setEditable(false) is called.

createControl

protected void createControl(com.ibm.swt.widgets.Composite parent)
Hook to actually create the text widget. Here are the steps carried out by this method:
  • a new LpexView is constructed
  • its name parameter is set based on the IFile input element
  • initializeLpexView() is called to set "Open File" preference panel settings and allow the user to set their own parameters for this view
  • initializeWidgetContents() is called to load the file in
  • a new LpexWindow is created and associated with the LpexView
  • listeners are added to the new text widget
  • the updateProfile command is called.
  • the user must add their own LPEX actions and commands by extending updateProfile(), which is called when we are notified of the completion of the updateProfile command.
See Also:
initializeLpexView(), initializeWidgetContents(), updateProfile()

initializeLpexView

protected void initializeLpexView()
Hook to initialize a newly instantiated LpexView. Called from createControl().

Here are loaded any "Open File" preferences panel settings (sequenceNumbers and sourceEncoding). Extend this method to set any file/view-specific parameters for this LpexView (use getLpexView() to access it). The updateProfile command will be called later.

See Also:
createControl(com.ibm.swt.widgets.Composite)

updateProfile

protected void updateProfile()
Extend this method to define your own LPEX actions (and assign them to keys), and your own LPEX commands. Called when a new LpexTextViewer is created (an LPEX document is opened), and whenever the updateProfile command is issued.

handleDispose

protected void handleDispose()
Frees all resources allocated by this viewer.

getLpexWindow

Retrieve the underlying LPEX text widget window (an SWT Composite).
Returns:
null if the text widget was not yet created, or was disposed

null if the text widget was not yet created, or was disposed

getTextWidget

public com.ibm.swt.custom.StyledText getTextWidget()
This method returns null. In TextViewer, this method returns the StyledText control, its underlying text widget.

Note: Do not use this method in LpexTextViewer. LpexTextViewer uses an LPEX text widget, which consists of an LpexWindow (an SWT Composite) and an LpexView, rather than a StyledText widget.

Specified by:
getTextWidget in interface com.ibm.jface.text.ITextViewer
See Also:
ITextViewer.getTextWidget(), getLpexWindow(), getLpexView()

setAutoIndentStrategy

public void setAutoIndentStrategy(com.ibm.jface.text.IAutoIndentStrategy strategy,
                                  java.lang.String contentType)
This method does nothing.

In TextViewer, this method registers an IAutoIndentStrategy for the given content type. LPEX language parsers handle their own autoindent.

Specified by:
setAutoIndentStrategy in interface com.ibm.jface.text.ITextViewer
See Also:
ITextViewer.setAutoIndentStrategy(com.ibm.jface.text.IAutoIndentStrategy, java.lang.String)

setEventConsumer

public void setEventConsumer(com.ibm.jface.text.IEventConsumer consumer)
IEventConsumer - implementers can register with an ITextViewer and receive VerifyEvents before the text viewer touches them. If the IEventConsumer marks an event as processed, the text viewer will ignore it.

For example, keys consumed by a content-assist popup should not be again processed by us. This is not awt's e.consume(), but that's the way Eclipse operates...

See Also:
ITextWidget.setEventConsumer(com.ibm.jface.text.IEventConsumer)

setIndentPrefixes

public void setIndentPrefixes(java.lang.String[] indentPrefixes,
                              java.lang.String contentType)
Set the strings that are used as prefixes when lines of the given content type are shifted using the shift operation. The prefixes are considered equivalent. Thus "\t" and " " can both be used as prefix characteres. Shift right always inserts the indentPrefixes[0]. Shift left removes all of the specified prefixes.
Specified by:
setIndentPrefixes in interface com.ibm.jface.text.ITextViewer
See Also:
ITextViewer.setIndentPrefixes(java.lang.String[], java.lang.String)

setUndoManager

public void setUndoManager(com.ibm.jface.text.IUndoManager undoManager)
This method does nothing in LpexTextViewer. LPEX uses its own built-in undo manager (with unlimited undo/redo capabilitites), therefore it does not support IUndoManager.
Specified by:

doSaveAction

public boolean doSaveAction(com.ibm.eclipse.core.runtime.IProgressMonitor monitor)
                     throws com.ibm.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException
Do a straight save of the LPEX text widgets contents to the local IFile / File. This method must be used to do a save, as LpexTextViewer doesn't keep its IDocument up-to-date. Also, this method takes into account the save.trim and save.textLimit parameters of the LPEX save command.
Returns:
true save performed, or false cannot save directly from LPEX

Return this text viewer's stream-oriented IDocument. Note that LPEX doesn't maintain this IDocument in sync with the contents of its text widget.

getTopIndex

public int getTopIndex()
Return the ZERO-based index of the visible document line with the smallest line number.
See Also:
ITextWidget.getTopIndex()

setTopIndex

public void setTopIndex(int index)
Scrolls the edit window so that ZERO-based index is the smallest line number of all visible lines.

Preferred method: in LPEX you may consider various options, depending on the intended usage. For example, to set the cursor in the edit window on a certain line in the document: 

   LpexView lpexView = getLpexView();
   lpexView.doCommand("locate emphasis line " + index+1);
   lpexView.triggerAction(lpexView.actionId("textWindow"));
To position the line that contains the cursor on a certain screen row: 
   LpexView lpexView = getLpexView();
   lpexView.doCommand("set cursorRow " + row);
   lpexView.doCommand("screenShow");

You must consider certain characteristics of the LPEX edit window, such as:

  • some elements (lines) in the document may be hidden
  • the current element must always be visible
  • elements are laid out such that there is never any wasted space at the top of the edit area
  • there may be wasted space only at the bottom of the edit area, if there are not enough visible elements to fill it.
See Also:
ITextWidget.setTopIndex(int)

getVisibleLinesInViewPort

protected int getVisibleLinesInViewPort()
Return the number of rows displayable in the viewport. The actual document lines displayed may be fewer, when the document is shorter or some lines are not visible.

Preferred method: use getLpexView().queryInt("rows").

getBottomIndexEndOffset

public int getBottomIndexEndOffset()

See Also:

customizeDocumentCommand

protected void customizeDocumentCommand(com.ibm.jface.text.DocumentCommand command)
Hook called on receipt of a VerifyEvent. The event has been translated into a DocumentCommand, which can now be manipulated by interested parties.

The implementation of this method does nothing. In TextViewer, as default behaviour, this hook forwards the command to the installed IAutoIndentStrategy.

See Also:
verifyText(com.ibm.swt.events.VerifyEvent)

isSafeToChangePresentation

public boolean isSafeToChangePresentation()
Return whether the presentation of the widget content can be safely manipulated using selection-based operations. If the call returns true, the visual impact such as flashing is not disturbing. If the call returns false, the operation can be applied but might cause a temporary unsteady visual appearance.
See Also:
ITextWidget.isSafeToChangePresentation()

shift

protected void shift(boolean useDefaultPrefixes,
                     boolean right)
If a block of text is selected, insert prefixes[0] at the beginning of each line of the block on shift right. On shift left, test whether each of the selected lines start with one of the specified prefixes and if so, remove such prefixes.

shift

protected void shift(java.lang.String[] prefixes,
                     boolean right,
                     int startLine,
                     int endLine)
If a block of text is selected, insert prefixes[0] at the beginning of each line of the block on shift right. On shift left, test whether each of the selected lines start with one of the specified prefixes and if so, remove such prefixes.

addPresentation

protected void addPresentation(com.ibm.jface.text.TextPresentation presentation)
This method does nothing. LPEX parsers set display attributes to text in the parsed document. Also, LPEX marks can be set with certain style, visibility, and protection attributes. See the mark and related parameters.

In TextViewer, this method adds the specified presentation to the viewer's text widget style information.

replacePresentation

protected void replacePresentation(com.ibm.jface.text.TextPresentation presentation)
This method does nothing. LPEX parsers set display attributes to text in the parsed document. Also, LPEX marks can be set with certain style, visibility, and protection attributes. See the mark and related parameters.

In TextViewer, this method replaces the text widget's style information with the given presentation.

changeTextPresentation

public void changeTextPresentation(com.ibm.jface.text.TextPresentation presentation,
                                   boolean controlRedraw)
This method does nothing. LPEX parsers set display attributes to text in the parsed document. Also, LPEX marks can be set with certain style, visibility, and protection attributes. See the mark and related parameters.

In TextViewer, this method applies in the text widget the color information of the specified text presentation.
